jql_About.description:
This module (JQueryLike) was inspired by the idea that some JQuery was too good to ditch.
It is developed in a modular fashion and uses plain ES20xx, so not really (or really not, take your pick) suitable for older browsers.
The module originally was written in 2021. In 2023 it was rewritten in a classfree object oriented fashion, inspired by a Douglas Crockford presentation. This means you won't find any this in the code.
It is not a replacement for JQuery. Consider it a subset of JQuery alike methods to retrieve, create, modify or manipulate (collections of) HTML elements in your HTML document.
This document is completely built using JQL. Another example/demo-version can be found @kooiinc.github.io/JQL/TestNDemo.
In the following you'll find documentation for usage of the module, divided into 4 chapters:
  • INSTANCE
    : all methods applicable to a JQL instance;
  • STATIC
    : JQL static module methods;
  • POPUP
    : JQL includes a module to create (modal) popup messages;
  • DEBUGLOG
    : JQL includes a module to extensively log everything it does (you do with it).
For all examples $ is the imported JQL module (so import $ from "[location of JQL]").
Most examples can be run (use the [Try it] button). If elements are created/modified in an example, the result is shown within the item at hand (and removed after a few seconds) or in a popup. The examples deliberately use all kinds of JQL methods, to familiarize the reader with them.
source code @Github

instance_text.description:
Set the textcontent of all elements of the instance element collection.
When textValue is empty, returns the current textcontent of the first element of the instance element collection. Otherwise returns the JQL Instance.

instance_each.description:
Loops through every element of the instance collection and applies the given callback function to it.
The signature of the callback function is (element, [i]) => {...}. Elements that are not HTMLElement (e.g. Comment or text nodes) are not processed.
Click the [Try it] button twice and watch the method name headers for a demo.
const mNameElems = $(`.methodName`); const brown = `rgb(165, 42, 42)`; const currentColor = mNameElems.computedStyle(`color`); mNameElems.each( el => $(el).style({color: currentColor === brown ? `` : brown}) );

params.cb: Function. The lambda function to appy to every element of the collection.

instance_remove.description:
Removes every element of the instance element collection, or, when selector is present, removes every child element from of the instance element collection for which the selector applies.
$(`p`).remove(); // => all

are removed from the document $(`p`).remove(`.toBeRemoved`); // => all are removed from the document $(`p`).remove(`:not(.keepMe)`); // => all

except `` are removed from the document

params.selector: string. A (valid) css selector string, e.g. #someDiv.someClass

instance_computedStyle.description:
Retrieves the computed style for the given property the first element of the instance collection.
See also
Style.computed
.
$.editCssRule(`.redEx {color: red; font-weight: bold}`); $(`

Hello!

`, /*[root element]*/); popup.show( {content: `$(".redEx").computedStyle("color"): ${ $(`.redEx`).computedStyle(`color`) }
$(".redEx").computedStyle("font-weight"): ${ $(`.redEx`).computedStyle(`font-weight`) }` } );

instance_isEmpty.description:
returns: true if the JQL Instance collection is empty, otherwise false.
Note: alternatively you can use [JQL instance].is.empty.
const someDiv = $(`
Hello!
`, /*[root element]*/); popup.show( {content: `someDiv.isEmpty() => ${someDiv.isEmpty()}
someDiv.find$("span:first-child").isEmpty() => ${ someDiv.find$(`span:first-child`).isEmpty()}`, callback: () => $(`[data-id="tmpEx"]`).remove()} );

instance_getData.description:
Retrieve the value of a data-attribute. When valueWhenFalsy is present, it will return that value if the data-attribute does not exist.
See also:
data
.
const popup = $.popup(); const thisBttn = $(evt.target); const action = thisBttn.getData(`action`); const undef = thisBttn.getData(`nonexistent`); const undefWithDefaultValue = thisBttn.getData(`nothing`, `NOCANDO`); popup.show( {content: [`action: ${action}`, `undef: ${undef}`, `undefWithDefaultValue: ${undefWithDefaultValue}`].join(`
`)} );

params.dataAttribute: string. The data-attribute to query, e.q. width

params.valueWhenFalsy: Any. The value to return when the data-attribute was not found.

instance_is.description:
[JQL instance].is is a static property. To retrieve a value of it use [JQL instance].is[key]. If the JQL instance element collection is empty, the return values of all properties except empty will be "n/a".
[JQL instance].is keys:
  • writable: is the first element of the JQL instance collection writable?
  • visible: is the first element of the JQL instance collection visible in the DOM?
  • disabled: is the first element of the JQL instance collection disabled?
  • open: is the first element of the JQL instance collection open (<details> or <dialog>)
  • modal: is the first element of the JQL instance collection modal (<dialog>)
  • empty: is the JQL instance element collection empty?
  • virtual: does the JQL instance only exist in memory?
const inpDisabled = $(``, /*[root element]*/); const is = inpDisabled.is; const features = [ `visible? ${is.visible}`, `disabled? ${is.disabled}`, `writable? ${is.writable}`, ]; popup.show( {content: `${$(`#disabledInput`).outerHtml.replace(/

${features.join(`
`)}

`} );

instance_hasClass.description:
For (the list of) className(s) determine if the first (root) element of the JQL Instance element collection contains (one of) the classNames.
const tmpDiv = $(`
Hello world
`); popup.show( {content: `tmpDiv.hasClass("one", "tree") => ${tmpDiv.hasClass("one, tree")}
tmpDiv.hasClass("one", "four") => ${tmpDiv.hasClass("one, four")}
tmpDiv.hasClass("five") => ${tmpDiv.hasClass("five")}`, callback: () => $(`.one.two`).remove()} );

instance_replace.description:
Replace [oldChild] (a DOM Element, css selector or a JQL instance) within the first (root) element of the instance element collection with a new JQL Instance
const div = $.virtual(`
Hi there!
I shall be replaced...
Me Too!
`); const newDiv = $.virtual(`
Formerly known as "div.oldD"
`).style({color: `red`}); popup.show( { content: div, closeAfter: 3, callback: () => popup.show({ content: div.replace(`.oldD`, newDiv), closeAfter: 3 }), });

params.oldChild: JQL instance | HTMLElement | String. If String, a (valid) css selector.

instance_replaceMe.description:
Replace the JQL Instance with a new JQL Instance.
Note: If the new instance is
virtual
, it will be added to the DOM tree on replacement.
const oldDiv = $.virtual(`
I shall be replaced...
`); const newDiv = $.virtual(`
I have replaced div#oldD!
`); popup.show( { content: oldDiv, closeAfter: 3, callback: () => popup.show({ content: oldDiv.replaceMe(newDiv).style({color: `red`}), closeAfter: 3 }), });

instance_toDOM.description:
Add a 'virtual' element (an element created in memory, using the [instance].virtual method) to the DOM. Defaults to adding the element to the body, but root may be any element (if the DOM allows it). See
virtual
documentation for an example.

instance_first.description:
Returns the first element of the JQL element collection or a new JQL Instance derived from the first element of the JQL Instance element collection. When asJQLInstance is true, the element is returned as a new JQL Instance (equivalent to
first$
), otherwise a DOM Node.
const jqlElems = $(`#navigation li[data-key]`); popup.show( {content: $(`
jqlElems.collection.length: ${jqlElems.collection.length},
outerHTML jqlElems.first(): ${jqlElems.first().outerHTML.replace(/`)} );

instance_append.description:
Appends one ore more elements to each element of the JQL Instance collection (for real, in the DOM tree).
Notes:
  • when the JQL Instance to append to is empty, nothing will happen.
  • If (one of) elems2Append consists of html string(s), they should contain valid html (e.g., no flow content in elements expecting phrasing content, so for example no <h1> within <p>). The HTML is always sanitized.
  • Already existing (in DOM) elems2Append are moved to the JQL instance when the JQL instance to append to has one element in its collection, but
  • elems2Append (if JQL instance or Node) are cloned and stripped of their id when the JQL instance collection to append to contains more then one element.
$.editCssRule(`.appended { color: red; cursor: pointer; }`); const toAppendJQLInstance = $.virtual(`
I am an appended JQL instance ...
`) .on(`click`, () => alert(`HELLO!`)); const elem2Append = $(`
Hi there! Wait a sec ...
`, /*[root element]*/) .append( toAppendJQLInstance, `Appended text`, `
Appended html string
`, Object.assign( document.createElement(`div`), {textContent: `Appended element`}) ); setTimeout(() => popup.show( { content: toAppendJQLInstance.html(`Now I am appended to the popup element, you can still click me`), }), 1500);

params....elems2Append: string[] | HTMLElement[]| Text[] | Comment[] | JQL instance[]

instance_appendTo.description:
Appends the collection of one JQL instance to another instance, so injects the element(s) of [JQl instance element collection] to each element of appendTo (for real, injected and visible in the DOM tree).
Note: this returns appendTo (so, the parent JQL Instance).
$.editCssRule(`#tmpEx {color: blue; font-weight: normal}`); $.editCssRule(`#tmpEx div {color: red; font-weight: bold}`); const helloWorld = $(`

Hello World

`, /*[root element]*/); const div2Append = $$(`
And bye again
`); setTimeout(() => div2Append.appendTo(helloWorld), 1500);

static_delegate.description:
Create targeted event listeners/handlers.
Note: non bubbling events are delegated using {capture: true}. This concerns the following events:
  • load
  • unload
  • scroll
  • focus
  • blur
  • DOMNodeRemovedFromDocument
  • DOMNodeInsertedIntoDocument
  • loadstart
  • progress
  • error
  • abort
  • load
  • loadend
  • pointerenter
  • pointerleave
  • readystatechange
The example creates a click listener/handler for the header of this chapter ("delegate").
$.delegate( `click`, `#static_delegate`, evt => { if (!evt.target.dataset.after) { evt.target.setAttribute(`data-after`, `1`); return $.editCssRule(` #${evt.target.id}::after { content: " HI! My name is U.S.E. Less. Click to add or remove me..."; color: green; }` ); } $.removeCssRule(`#${evt.target.id}::after`); return evt.target.removeAttribute(`data-after`); } ); $(`#static_delegate`).trigger(`click`);

params.type: string. Event type (e.g. click) to listen for

params.origin: string. Optional css identifying the element to assign listener to (e.g. #someId)

instance_dimensions.description:
Retrieve the actual dimensions of the first (root) element in the instance element collection. It actually returns the result of getBoundingClientRect, see MDN for interpretation of the values.
Note: dimensions is a property, not a function. Usage [JQL instance].dimensions.
const dimElem = $(`

Hello, where am I at the moment?

`, /*[root element]*/) .style({color: `red`, fontWeight: `bold`}); const dims = JSON.stringify(dimElem.dimensions, null, 2) .replace(/[}{"]/g, ``).trim().replace(/\n/g, `
`); popup.show( {content: dims} );

instance_duplicate.description:
Duplicate a JQL instance to memory (default) or to DOM (append to root).
The elements within the instance are cloned, their id's are removed and the resulting NodeList is converted to a new JQL Instance.
Note check the cloned nodes classList/properties/attributes: you may want to change them before injecting to DOM.
const someElem = Object.assign( $.editCssRule(`.someClass`, {color: `brown`}); $(`
hello
`, /*[root]*/).duplicate(true, /*[root]*/); $( `.someClass`, /*[root]*/ ) .append($.text(` world!`)) .prepend($.text(`We say: `)) .each(el => el.setAttribute(`id`, `_${ Math.floor(10000 + Math.random() * 10000).toString(16)}` )) .duplicate(true, /*[root]*/) .removeClass(`someClass`) .addClass(`tmp`) .text(` That's right folks. Bye!`, true); /** output in DOM
We say: hello world!
We say: hello world!
We say: hello world! That's right folks. Bye!
We say: hello world! That's right folks. Bye!
*/

instance_css.description:
Style each element of the element collection of the JQL Instance within the custom style sheet (<style id="JQLStylesheet">), using an intermediate (generated, random) or given class name. Preferably use key-value pairs, even when assigning a single property.
Notes
  • the intermediate className starts with "jQLClass-". There will be one intermediate class name per element. Subsequent .css calls will modify the rule for the generated class name.
  • using !important will be honored, e.g. {color: `green !important`}
// no className $(`

Hello #1

`, /*[root element]*/) .css({ paddingLeft: `4px`, color: `white`, backgroundColor: `#000` } ); popup.show( {content: `intermediate className: ${$.node(`#noClass`).classList.shift()}`} ); // className $(`

Hello #2

`, /*[root element]*/) .css({ className: `leftRedBorder`, paddingLeft: `4px`, color: `green`, borderLeft: `12px solid red` } );
See also [JQL instance].Style.inSheet

params.keyOrKvPairs: Object | string. If you want to use a className for the css, add a className property to the Object.

params.value: string | undefined. If value is a string, keyOrKvPairs must be a string too.

instance_empty.description:
Remove contents for all elements of the JQL instance element collection.
Equivalent to
clear
instance_empty.returnValue: JQL Instance. An instance with elements without any content.

instance_clear.description:
Remove contents for all elements of the JQL instance element collection.
$([`

I hope they won't remove this!

`, `
Me too!
`], /*[root element]*/); setTimeout( () => $(`[data-id="tmpEx"]`).clear(), 1500); setTimeout( () => $(`.metoo`).text(`The did it didn't they?`), 2500);

instance_hide.description:
Hide each element of the element collection of the JQL instance.
Note: hiding changes the css display property to "none". It may be more useful to use a css class for this.
const cleanup = self => { self[0].closest(`.divExClass`).remove(); $.removeCssRule(`.showHide`); $.removeCssRule(`button#hide, button#show, button#cleanup`); }; $.editCssRule(`.showHide { display: block; color: red; font-weight: bold; }`); $.editCssRule(`button#hide, button#show, button#cleanup { margin-right: 5px; }`); const elem = $(`
Hello World!
`, /*[root element]*/); elem.append($.virtual(``) .on( `click`, evt => $(evt.target.closest(`.divExClass`).querySelector(`.showHide`)).hide() ) ); elem.append($.virtual(``) .on( `click`, evt => $(evt.target.closest(`.divExClass`).querySelector(`.showHide`)).show() ) ); elem.append( $.virtual(``) .on( `click`, (_, self) => cleanup(self) ) );

instance_removeAttribute.description: Remove some attribute from each element of the element collection of the JQL Instance.

instance_removeClass.description:
Remove classNames from for each element of the element collection of the JQL Instance. Class names can be one or more strings.
$.editCssRule(`.exTest { color: red; font-weight: bold; }`); const exElem = $(`
Hello World!
`, /*[root element]*/); setTimeout(() => exElem.find$(`span`).removeClass(`exTest`), 1500);

instance_replaceClass.description:
Swap className with nwClassnames for each element of the element collection of the JQL Instance. Enables replacing a class name with one or more class name(s)
const divEx = $(`
Hello World!
`, /*[root element]*/); $.editCssRule(`.redEx { color: red; }`); $.editCssRule(`.redExUl { text-decoration: underline; }`); setTimeout(() => divEx.replaceClass(`divExClass`, `redEx`, `redExUl`), 1500);

params....nwClassNames: string[]. The class name(s) to replace className with.

instance_find.description:
Find one or more elements within the first (root) element of the JQL Instance collection using a css query (e.g. '.someClass').
popup.show( {content: $(`.docs`).find(`#instance_find`)?.[0].outerHTML.replace(/

instance_find$.description:
Find one or more elements within the JQL Instance collection using a css query (e.g. '.someClass') starting from the root element of the collection, and return a new JQL Instance from it's result
popup.show( {content: $(`.docs`).find$(`#instance_find_D`)?.HTML.get(true, true)} ) // ^ note #[...] css selector can not contain $

instance_first$.description:
Retrieve nth Element (Number) or element from selector (css selector) from the collection of the JQL Instance and return that as a new JQL Instance (if it exists, otherwise undefined).
const fromQS = $(`.docs`).first$(`#instance_first_D`); const first$WithIndexExample = () => popup.show( {content: $(`.docs h3`).first$(17).HTML.get(true, true)} ); popup.show( {content: fromQS.HTML.get(true, true), callback: first$WithIndexExample} ); // non existing ... const jqlElem = $(`.docs`).first$(30001); popup.show( {content: `
non existing: ${jqlElem.outerHtml}
`} );

params.indexOrSelector: Number | string. If string, a (valid) css selector.

instance_on.description:
Add listener and handler lambda('s) for the JQL Instance root element.
The lambda signature is [handler function](event, JQLInstance).
See
the toggleClass documentation
for examplary usage.

params....callback: Function[]. One or more handler functions (lambda's)

instance_outerHtml.description:
Retrieves the complete html for the first (root) element of the JQL Instance.
Note: .outerHtml is a property (not a method).
const exElem = $$(`
HelloWorld!
`, /*[root element]*/); popup.show( {content: `exElem.outerHtml => ${exElem.outerHtml.replace(/`} );

instance_parent.description:
Get the direct parentNode of the first (root) element of the JQL Instance (as new JQL Instance).
Notes:
  • .parent is a property (not a method)
  • In (the unlikely) case there is no parent, .parent returns the original JQL instance.

instance_html.description:
Get (inner-) html of the first (root) element in the collection of the JQL instance or set html for each element of the collection.
Overwrites current html of the elements, or appends (append: true) the value to it.
Note: htmlValue is always sanitized.
const someDiv = $(`
Hello world
`, /*[root element]*/); setTimeout(() => { $(`[data-id="tmpEx"] span`, , /*[root element]*/).html(`universe!`); setTimeout(() => $(`[data-id="tmpEx"] span`, /*[root element]*/).html(` And by again`, true), 1500); }, 1500);

instance_htmlFor.description:
Sets/adds/removes html for an element within the collection of the JQL Instance (identified with a css query).
Notes:
  • html from htmlString is always sanitized.
  • if htmlString is empty, the element content is removed.
const someDiv = $(`
Hello world etc.
`, /* root element */); setTimeout(() => { popup.show( { content: someDiv.duplicate().htmlFor(`span:first-child`, `UNIVERSE`), callback: () => $(`[data-id="tmpEx"]`).remove(), closeAfter: 5 }); }, 1500);

instance_prepend.description:
Injects one or more elements at the start of each element of the collection of a JQL Instance.
The syntax equals
append
.
Notes:
  • When the JQL Instance to append to is empty, nothing will happen.
  • If (one of) elems2Prepend consists of html string(s), they should contain valid html (e.g., no flow content in elements expecting phrasing content, so for example no <h1> within <p>). The HTML is always sanitized.
  • Already existing (in DOM) elems2Prepend are moved to the JQL instance when the JQL instance to prepend to has one element in its collection, but
  • elems2Prepend (if JQL instance or Node) are cloned and stripped of their id when the JQL instance collection to append to contains more then one element.
$.editCssRule(`#tmpEx {color: green; font-weight: bold;}`); $(`
... hi there!
`, /*[root element]*/).prepend(`
Hello and also ...
`);

params....elems2Prepend: string | HTMLElement | Text | Comment | JQL Instance (one or more)

instance_prop.description:
Set a property (e.g. title or disabled) value for each element of the JQL Instance element collection. Or, without [value] retrieve the value of [property] of the first (root) element from the JQL Instance collection.
Notes:
  • Properties are validated (so, e.g. no onclick etc. - see example).
  • See all information on properties and attributes @javascript.info
const exElem = $(`
Hello World!
`, /*[root element]*/); exElem.prop(`title`, `now I have a title`); exElem.prop(`onclick`, `javascript:alert("hello!")`); // hover the created element (below) to check the title property (before it disappears) popup.show( {content: `exElem.prop("title") => ${exElem.prop("title")}
exElem.prop("onclick") => ${exElem.prop("onclick")}`, closeAfter: 4} );

instance_attr.description:
Get (keyOrObj string, [value] empty) attribute for the root element of the JQL Instance or set attributes for the first (root) element of the JQL Instance element collection.
Notes:
  • to set data-attribute or style, use {[data/style]: {[key]: [value], ...} (see example)
  • To set multiple class-names, use a comma separated string of class names (e.g. [instance].attr({class: `class1, class2 ... classn`}))
  • All attributes are validated (so, e.g. no onclick etc.)
  • Setting an attribute value ([keyOrObj] returns the JQL instance.
  • See all information on attributes and properties @javascript.info
const someDiv = $(`
Hi, let me get some attributes
`, /*[root element]*/); someDiv.attr( { title: `Yes, I have a title now!`, class: `volatile`, data: {myTitle: `title as data`}, onclick: alert("will not be set!")} ); const [ myDataId, myTitle, myClass, myDataTitle, myOnclick ] = [ someDiv.attr(`data-id`), someDiv.attr(`title`), someDiv.attr(`class`), someDiv.attr(`data-my-title`), someDiv.attr(`onclick`)]; popup.show({ content: [ `someDiv.attr("data-id"): ${myDataId}`, `someDiv.attr("data-my-title"): ${myDataTitle}`, `someDiv.attr("title"): ${myTitle}`, `someDiv.attr("class"): ${myClass}`, `someDiv.attr(`onclick`), ].join(`
`) });

instance_addClass.description:
Add [classNames] to each element of the element collection of the JQL instance. ...classNames Can be one or more strings.
$.editCssRule(`#tmpEx.warnUser {color: red; font-weight: bold;}`); $.editCssRule(`.user:before {content: 'Hi user! '}`); $(`
This is not very useful
`, /*[root element]*/) .addClass(`warnUser`, `user`);

instance_About.description:
All methods applicable for an instance of JQL.
An instance of JQL is anything created with the imported JQL constructor (here $).
// in html use import $ from "//kooiinc.github.io/JQL/Bundle/jql.min.js"; // or any location you downloaded the JQL library to
As said, JQL can be used to retrieve, create, modify or manipulate (collections of) HTML elements.
The syntax [imported JQL constructor](input[, root, position]):
  • input: A (n Array of) HTML string(s), HTMLElement, JQL instance or a (valid) css selector
  • root: (HTMLElement | JQL Instance) The root element for the [input]. Default is document.body. When root is a JQL Instance, the first element of its collection is presumed to be the root.
  • position: (string) For creation of elements: where the instance should end up (relative to the root). You can use:
    • "beforebegin": (before [root], so [root] will be the first sibling of [input])
    • "afterbegin": (after the begin of [root], so [input] as first element of [root])
    • "beforeend": (before the end of [root], so [input] as last element of [root]))
    • "afterend": (after [root], so [input] will be the first sibling of [root])
Every JQL Instance has a three relevant static properties:
  • collection: Array<HTMLelement>: an Array with the collection of elements contained in the instance (so, $(`.someClass`).collection can contain 0 to n elements)
  • isVirtual: boolean: true if the instance is virtual (i.e. not (yet) in the DOM-tree)
  • isJQL: boolean: true if the instance is a JQL instance (so $.nodes(`.someClass`).isJQL is false) -
    see [JQL].nodes
Examples:
  • const exampleDiv = $(`<div id="example">Hello <div class="example">world</div></div>`);
  • const exampleDiv = $(`<div id="example"> world</div>`, $.node(`.example:first-child`), "afterbegin");
  • const exampleDiv = $(`meta, style`, document.documentElement);
  • const exampleDiv = $([`<div class="a">A</div>`, `<div class="B">B</div>`]);
  • const exampleDivs = $(`.example`);
  • const exampleSubDivs = $(`#example`).find$(`.example`);
  • ... etc
Where a method's return value is JQL Instance, method chaining is possible.
$.editCssRules(`#tmpEx {color: green;}`, `.helloworld {font-weight: bold;}`); $(`
Hello world.
`, /*[root element]*/) .addClass(`helloworld`) .append(` And the rest of the universe!`) .text(` (will disappear shortly)`, true);
In the following every instance method is documented.

static_About.description:
Static methods are methods you can call using the imported JQL module.
For example, when imported as $, $.editCssRule(...) or const popup = $.popup().
JQL also knows one static property for use with element creation: [imported JQL constructor].at for mapping a created elements' position relative to its parent, in other words: the position parameter from the
JQL constructor
.
Its properties are ([input] is the element to add, [root] the element to add to):
  • BeforeBegin: (before [root], so [root] will be the first sibling of [input])
  • AfterBegin: (after the begin of [root], so [input] as first element of [root])
  • BeforeEnd: (before the end of [root], so [input] as last element of [root]))
  • AfterEnd: (after [root], so [input] will be the first sibling of [root])
So, instead of $(`<div id="example">Hi world</div>`, /*some root element*/, "afterbegin"), you can use $(`<div id="example">Hi world</div>`, /*some root element*/, $.at.AfterBegin)
$.editCssRule(`h2.hello, h3.hello {margin: 0.3rem 0}`); const elemContainer = $.virtual(`
`).append($.virtual(`

world

`)); $.virtual(`

Hello

`, elemContainer.single(`.hello`), $.at.BeforeBegin); popup.show({content: elemContainer, callback: () => $.removeCssRule(`h2.hello, h3.hello`)});

instance_setData.description:
Set data-attribute(s) for each element of the the JQL Instance element collection. The attributes must be key-value pairs.
See also:
data
.
const someDiv = $(`Hello world`, /*[root element]*/); $.editCssRule("[data-goodbye]::after { content: '...'attr(data-goodbye); }"); setTimeout( () => { someDiv.setData({id: "temporary", goodbye: "and bye again"}); setTimeout(() => $("[data-id='temporary']").remove(), 2500); }, 1500);

instance_show.description:
Show each element of the element collection of the JQL instance.
Note: this will reset the display css property. For more granular showing/hiding elements, use your own classes.
const cleanup = self => { self[0].closest(`.divExClass`).remove(); $.removeCssRule(`.showHide`); $.removeCssRule(`button#hide, button#show, button#cleanup`); }; $.editCssRule(`.showHide { display: block; color: red; font-weight: bold; }`); $.editCssRule(`button#hide, button#show, button#cleanup { margin-right: 5px; }`); const elem = $(`
Hello World!
`, /*[root element]*/); elem.append($.virtual(``) .on( `click`, evt => $(evt.target.closest(`.divExClass`).querySelector(`.showHide`)).hide() ) ); elem.append($.virtual(``) .on( `click`, evt => $(evt.target.closest(`.divExClass`).querySelector(`.showHide`)).show() ) ); elem.append( $.virtual(``) .on( `click`, (_, self) => cleanup(self) ) );

instance_single.description:
When indexOrSelector has a value, retrieves the first matching element from a JQL Instance collection, or retrieves the first (root) element from the collection. The result will be a new JQL Instance (its collection may be empty).
indexOrSelector is CSS Selector: $(`
Hello world (1)
Hello world (2)
`, /*[root element]*/); popup.show( {content: `$("[data-id='tmpEx']").single(".test").outerHtml.replace(/</g, "<")
${$("[data-id='tmpEx']").single(".test").outerHtml.replace(/</g, "<")}`, callback: () => $("[data-id='tmpEx']").remove()} ); indexOrSelector is empty: $(`
Hello world (1)
Hello world (2)
`, /*[root element]*/); popup.show( {content: `$("[data-id='tmpEx']").single().outerHtml.replace(/</g, "<")
${$("[data-id='tmpEx']").single().outerHtml.replace(/</g, "<")}`, callback: () => $("[data-id='tmpEx']").remove()} ); indexOrSelector is number:
Note: retrieve a single element by number is zero based.
$(`
Hello world (1)
Hello world (2)
Hello world (3)
`, /*[root element]*/); popup.show( {content: `$(".test_").single(1).outerHtml.replace(/</g, "<")
${$(".test").single(1).outerHtml.replace(/ $("[data-id='tmpEx']").remove()} );

params.indexOrSelector: string | number. An optional (valid) css selector.

instance_style.description:
Style each element of the of the JQL Instance element collection inline, so <div style="[the style from parameters]">. If keyOrKvPairs is a string and value is not empty, will set a single style value. Preferably use key-value pairs.
Note: using !important will be honored, e.g. {color: `green !important`}.
Equivalent to
[JQL instance].Style.inline

instance_toNodeList.description:
Copy the JQL Instance element collection into a NodeList. It may be a way to duplicate a collection of nodes (see example).
Notes:
  • the list is not a live NodeList. In other words: the nodes are copies of the original (and only exist in memory)
  • the eventual id of the copied nodes is removed (element id's must be unique). See also the .duplicate method
// create 2 nodes in the DOM tree and copy the elements as NodeList const nodes = $([ `
Hello
`, `
World
` ]).toNodeList(); // change the text and color of the nodes in the list for (const node of nodes) { node.textContent += `!`; node.style.color = `red`; } // append the nodes (and colorize) $(/*[someElement to append to]*/).append(...nodes); /* initial:
Hello
World
new and appended to DOM:
Hello!
World!
*/

instance_trigger.description:
Trigger a handler for all elements of the the JQL Instance element collection.
Note: bubbling is always true ({bubbles: true}), because event handling in this library uses event delegation.
See the example @
the delegate documentation

params.SpecifiedEvent: Event. The event may be specified, e.g. MouseEvent. Defaults to generic Event

params.options: Object. Event options. Default {bubbles: true, cancelable: false, composed: false}

instance_toggleClass.description:
Toggle className (on/off) for each element of the JQL Instance element collection.
$.editCssRule(`.redEx { color: red; }`); $.editCssRule(`button#toggleColor, button#cleanup { margin: 0 5px; }`); const elem = $(`
Hello World!
`, /*[root element]*/); elem.append($.virtual(``) .on( `click`, (_, self) => $(self[0].closest(`.divExClass`)).toggleClass(`redEx`)) ); elem.append($.virtual(``) .on( `click`, (_, self) => self[0].closest(`.divExClass`).remove()) );

params.className: string. The class name to toggle (eg 'hidden')

instance_val.description:
Get or set the value of (the root element of) the JQL instance, where the first element is one of input, textarea or select HTMLElement.
When newValue is empty, return the current value, otherwise the JQL Instance. When newValue is not a string, the new value will be an empty string.
const input = $(``, /*[root element]*/); const valueResults = `input.val() => ${input.val()}
Empty it: input.val("") => ${ input.val("").val() }
New value: input.val("hi there") => ${input.val("hi there").val()}`; popup.show( {content: valueResults} );

static_virtual.description:
Create a HTML element, but don't add it to DOM (so, only in memory).
const inDOM = () => $.node(`.virtual`) ? `Yep` : `Nope`; const thisChapter = evt.target.closest(`.description`); const virtualElem = $.virtual(`
Hello
`) .append($.virtual(` world!`).style({color: `green`, fontWeight: `bold`})); popup.show( { content: `virtual element created. In DOM tree? ${inDOM()}. We'll add it to this chapter soon`, closeAfter: 2.5, callback: () => virtualElem.toDOM(thisChapter).append($(`
in DOM tree? ${inDOM()}
`)) // add to DOM tree here });

params.root: Node. The parent of the element to create

params.position: The position relative to the parent of the element to create

params.str: string. The text content of the node

static_popup.description:
Use the built in popup Factory. See
the documentation
.

popup_About.description: When initialized (e.g. const myPopup = [JQL].popup()), you can use the built in popup module. It contains 4 methods, documented in the following.

popup_create.description:
Create a popup. When isModalOrCallback is a boolean and true, the window can not be automatically closed, use removeModal for that.
When isModalOrCallback is a function it will be called after the popup is closed. Other truthy values create a modal popup.
Note: [popup].create is a legacy method. It is replaced with the more versatile (less convoluted)
show
method.
When modalCallback is a function, it will be called after a modal popup is closed.
The examples demonstrate both a modal popup and a regular one.

Hi. This box is really modal.
There is no close icon and clicking outside this box does nothing.
In other words: you can only close this using the button below.
Try clicking anywhere outside the box ...

Here's a popup message for you.

Close it by clicking the checkmark icon or anywhere outside the box

const { popup } = $; popup.create(`

Here's a popup message for you.

Close it by clicking the checkmark icon or anywhere outside the box

`); const $$ = $.virtual; const closeBttn = $$(``) .on(`click`, () => popup.removeModal()) const okMessage = () => popup.createTimed(`Modal closed, you're ok, bye.`, 2); const message = $$(`

Hi. This box is really modal.
There is no close icon and clicking outside this box does nothing.
In other words: you can only close this using the button below.
Try clicking anywhere outside the box ...

`).append($$(`

`).append(closeBttn)); popup.create(message, true, okMessage, "There's only one escape here!");

params.modalCallback: Function. Optional function to call after closing a modal popup.

params.modalWarning: Optional warning text when a user tries to close a modal popup without the preferred action.

popup_createTimed.description:
Create a (non modal) popup, that closes itself after closeAfter seconds.

Hi, this is a popup! I'll be active for 5 seconds (as long as you don't close me first).

const { popup } = $; popup.createTimed(`

Hi, this is a popup! I'll be active for 5 seconds (as long as you don't close me first).

`, 5);

params.message: string. A text or (valid) HTML string.

params.closeAfter: Number. The number of seconds after the popup closes itself. Default 2.

params.callback: Function. Optional function to call after closing the popup.

popup_removeModal.description:
Remove a modal popup. See the second example @
show
.

static_log.description:
Equivalent to
log
in
debugLog
, but for intermediate logging to console (so debugLog doesn't have to be set to 'on').
While loading this document this logging was called several times. See the console for that.

static_nodes.description:
Retrieve or more DOM Nodes from [root]. The equivalent of Array.from([root].querySelectorAll([css selector])).
Note: returns a real Array (not a NodeList), so all Array methods work on the result.
For example: $.nodes(`.allGreen`).map(elem => elem.textContent += ` I'm green!`);.

static_node.description: Retrieve a DOM Node from [root]. The equivalent of [root].querySelector([css selector]). For example: const firstGreen = $.node(`.allGreen`);.

static_createStyle.description:
Factory function that creates (or retrieves) a stylesheet with the given id in the head of the document and returns a function to create/modify style rules in that stylesheet.
See also
the setStyle documentation
.
const setMyStyling = $.createStyle(`mystyle`); setMyStyling(`body {margin: 2rem; font: normal 12px/15px verdana, arial;}`);

instance_prependTo.description:
Injects the current JQL Instance at the start of prependTo.
If prependTo is a HTML string, it is converted to a JQL Instance and thus validated.
The syntax equals
appendTo
.

debuglog_About.description:
To use extensive logging for debugging (or just follow the application flow) you can use a special object named debugLog. debugLog is a static property of the JQL module. Where a method returns debugLog (so itself) the result is chainable.
Logging by default is to the browser console, but you can also log to a specially created element within your document.
By default debug logging is not active.
See it in action in the JQL demo.
Note: errors when creating elements are always logged to the browser console.
// JQL imported as $ const { debugLog } = $; if (!debugLog.isOn()) { debugLog .on() .toConsole // See the following .off() .log(`We started logging to div#logBox, enjoy ...`); }
There are two extra properties in debugLog to note:
  • toConsole can be used to enable or disable logging to the browser console. Use toConsole.on() to enable, toConsole.off() to disable logging to the console.. By default logging to the console is enabled. If logging is not active, using toConsole.on/off will set the state for later usage.
  • reversed. By default logging (to screen) is from latest entry to the oldest. To log from first entry to the last you can use debugLog.reversed.on(), and vice versa use debugLog.reversed.off(). As with toConsole this is only useful if debug logging is active, and only if logging to console is off.

debuglog_isOn.description: Check if debug logging state is active.

debuglog_isVisible.description: When logging to screen is active, check if the special logging box is visible.

debuglog_on.description:
Activate debug logging. By default logs all to the browser console.
Use [JQL].debugLog.on().toConsole.off() to activate logging to screen.

debuglog_remove.description:
Removes and deactivates all logging. If applicable removes the log box from the DOM.
Note: reactivate debug logging with [JQL].debugLog.on().

debuglog_log.description:
Log one or more strings, either to the console or the DOM logging element. debugLog Must be on (so debugLog.isOn === true).
Note For custom log messages to the console (independent of debugLog.isOn) you can use the
static [JQL].log method
.

debuglog_hide.description: Hide the DOM log box, if applicable (not logging to console).

debuglog_show.description: Show the DOM log box, if applicable (not logging to console).

debuglog_clear.description: Remove all strings logged until now from DOM log box or browser console.

static_setStyle.description:
Alias
editCssRule
. The method is kept for backward compatibility.

static_removeCssRule.description:
Remove one or several css rule(s) (e.g. .someclass:after) from the custom JQL stylesheet (<style id="JQLStylesheet">).
const yn = item => item === undefined ? `Yep` : `Nope`; const div1 = $.virtual(`
I am div#div1
`); const div2 = $.virtual(`
I am div#div2
`); $.editCssRules( `#div1 {margin: 0.3rem; color: green; background-color: #EEE; }`, `#div2 {margin: 0.3rem; color: red; background-color: #EEE; }` ); popup.show( { content: $.virtual(`
`).append(div1, div2), callback: () => { $.removeCssRule(`#div1`, `#div2`); const rulesExist = [...$.node(`#JQLStylesheet`, document.documentElement).sheet.cssRules] .filter(r => r.cssText.startsWith(`#div1`) || r.cssText.startsWith(`#div1`)) popup.show( { content: `Rules removed, so we expect rulesExist?.cssText to be undefined. Is that so? ${yn(rulesExist?.cssText)}`, closeAfter: 5, }); } );

params....rules: string[]. One ore more css selectors

static_editCssRule.description:
Formerly known as
setStyle
.
On importing, JQL creates a custom stylesheet in the header (<style id="JQLStylesheet">. Within this stylesheet you can create, remove and/or modify style rules using [jql].editCssRule
You can use either real style rule string, or a selector and an Object defining the properties of that selector.
When a rule is valid and doesn't exist, it will be created. Existing rules are modified with the given parameters.
You can remove rule properties (e.g. color) or complete rules.
  • To remove one or more rule properties, use (for example) $.editCssRule(`#someDiv`, {removeProperties: {color: 1, border: 1}})
  • To completely remove a css rule, use (for example) $.editCssRule(`#someDiv`, {removeRule: 1}) OR use
    removeCssRule
// a rule string $.editCssRule(`#div1 {margin: 0.3rem; color: green; background-color: #EEE; }`); // an object $.editCssRule(`#div2`, {margin: "0.3rem", color: "red", backgroundColor: "#EEE"}); // -----------------------------------------------------^ Note: camelcased const div1 = $.virtual(`
I am div#div1
`, /*[root element]*/); const div2 = $.virtual(`
I am div#div2
`, /*[root element]*/); popup.show( { content: $.virtual(`
`).append(div1, div2), callback: () => $.removeCssRule(`#div1`, `#div2`) } );

params.ruleOrSelector: string. A css selector (e.g. div[data-form]) or a css rule (e.g. .redBold {color: red; font-weight: bold;})

params.ruleObject: Object<string, string> pptional. When [ruleOrSelector] is a css selector, an object with rule properties.

static_allowTag.description:
The creation of some html-tags are prohibited/not enabled by default (like <frameset>, or <script>). You can allow the creation of such tags using this static method.
Note: using allowTag may introduce security problems. Handle with care!

params.tag2Allow: string. The html tag to allow (e.g. media)

static_prohibitTag.description: The creation of most html-tags is allowed by default. You can prohibit the creation of a tag using this the prohibitTag method, e.g. $.prohibitTag(`dialog`).

params.tag2Prohibit: string. The html tag to prohibit (e.g. details)

instance_length.description:
The number of elements within the JQL instance element collection.
$(`

There are ${$(`h3`).length} <h3>-elements within this document

`, /*[root element]*/);

popup_show.description:
Create and display a popup 'window'. There is one parameter, which is an Object with the following properties.
  • content: (JQL instance | HTML string | string) the message to show;
  • [modal]: (Boolean) true makes the popup modal;
  • [closeAfter]: (Number) the number of seconds after which the popup closes itself (ignored when modal);
  • [callback]: (Function) a function that will be executed after closing the popup;
  • [warnMessage]: (JQL instance | HTML string | string) a warning shown when the user clicks outside a modal popup (which normally closes a popup).
The only property that should have a value is content.
The examples demonstrate a regular and modal popup.

Hi. This box is really modal.
There is no close icon and clicking outside this box does nothing.
In other words: you can only close this using the button below.
Try clicking anywhere outside the box ...

Here's a popup message for you.

Close it by clicking the checkmark icon or anywhere outside the box

const { popup } = $; popup.show({ content: `

Here's a popup message for you.

Close it by clicking the checkmark icon or anywhere outside the box

` } ); const $$ = $.virtual; const closeBttn = $$(``) .on(`click`, () => popup.removeModal()) const sayOK = () => popup.show( { content: `Modal closed, you're ok, bye.`, closeAfter: 2 } ); const message = $$(`

Hi. This box is really modal.
There is no close icon and clicking outside this box does nothing.
In other words: you can only close this using the button below.
Try clicking anywhere outside the box ...

`).append($$(`

`).append(closeBttn)); popup.show( { content: message, modal: true, callback: sayOK, warnMessage: `"In other words: <i>you can only close this using the <b>button</b> ...</i>"` } );

instance_data.description:
Delivers a utility Object to manipulate data-attributes of the first element of the JQL instance collection.
Notes:
  • [JQL instance].data is a static property;
  • [JQL instance].data's methods are applied to the first element of the JQL instance collection;
  • The handling of casing for data-attributes is a bit weird and poorly documented imho. In html and css a data-attribute like helloWorld will show up as hello-world, for setting of/retrieval from the dataset it should be helloWorld. The methods of [JQL instance].data mitigate this (in other words: you can always use either camelCased or dashed notation data-attributes here). The example should demonstrate this;
  • The methods .add and .remove return the JQL instance (so, you can chain from them).
The available methods:
  • all: Retrieves all data-attribute values (e.g. [JQL instance].data.all.someattribute);
  • get(key: string[, whenUndefined: any]) Retrieves the value of data-attribute with [key] (e.g. [JQL instance].data.get("someattribute"). whenUndefined (optional) will be returned when the data-attribute does not exist);
  • add({key1: value1, ..., keyn: valuen}) Sets one or more attribute values (e.g. [JQL instance].data.set({someattribute: "1"}));
  • remove(key: string) Removes the data-attribute with [key] (e.g. [JQL instance].data.remove("someattribute")).
See also
getData
and
setData
.
const helloWrld = $(`
Hello World again
`); $.editCssRule(`[data-is-universe]:after {content: ' ... and the universe!'; color: red;}`); helloWrld.data.add({isUniverse: true, something: "else", "dashed-prop-given": 1}); popup.show( { content: `helloWrld.data.all => ${JSON.stringify(helloWrld.data.all)}
helloWrld.data.get("something") => ${helloWrld.data.get(`something`)}
helloWrld.data.all.isUniverse => ${helloWrld.data.all.isUniverse}
helloWrld.data.all["is-universe] => ${helloWrld.data.all["is-universe"]}
helloWrld.data.get("is-universe") => ${helloWrld.data.get(`is-universe`)}
helloWrld.data.get("isUniverse") => ${helloWrld.data.get(`isUniverse`)}
helloWrld.data.get("dashed-prop-given") => ${helloWrld.data.get(`dashed-prop-given`)}
helloWrld.data.all.nonexisting => ${helloWrld.data.all.nonexisting}
helloWrld.data.get("nonexisting", "no sir, I'm not here") => ${ helloWrld.data.get("nonexisting", "no sir, I'm not here")}`, callback: () => helloWrld.data.remove("isUniverse"), // note: may also be .remove("is-universe") } );

instance_HTML.description:
Returns a utility object for retrieving inner-/outerHTML, replacing, inserting or appending html of the first element of the JQL instance element.
The available methods:
  • get([outer:boolean, escaped:boolean]) Retrieves the html. If [outer] is true, it will be the outerHTML, otherwise innerHTML. When [escaped] is true, the html will be escaped, meaning that you can display the html within another html element.
  • replace(html:string|JQL Instance) Replace the innerHTML with [string]
  • append(html:string|JQL Instance) Appends [string] to innerHTML
  • insert(html:string|JQL Instance) Inserts [string] to innerHTML
`
Notes:
  • replace, append and insert return the JQL instance.
  • When the [html] parameter is a JQL Instance, the outer HTML of the first element of its collection will be used.
const emptyEl = $.virtual(`
'nough said
`); const html = emptyEl.HTML; const emptyElOuterHtml1 = `created emptyEl: ${html.get(true, true)}`; html.replace(`HELLO`); const emptyElOuterHtml2 = `replace: ${html.get(true, true)}`; html.append($(` WORLD`)); const emptyElOuterHtml3 = `append: ${html.get(true, true)}`; const emptyElOuterHtml4 = `insert: ${html.insert($(`the obligatory ... `)).HTML.get(true, true)}`; // aggregate const report = $.virtual(`
${emptyElOuterHtml1}
${emptyElOuterHtml2}
${ emptyElOuterHtml3}
${emptyElOuterHtml4}
So, there we have it:
`).append(emptyEl); popup.show({ content: report } );

static_editCssRules.description:
Add one or more css rules (e.g. .redBold {color: red; font-weight: bold;}) to <style id="JQLStylesheet">.
const div1 = $.virtual(`
I am div#div1
`); const div2 = $.virtual(`
I am div#div2
`); $.editCssRules( `#div1 {margin: 0.3rem; color: green; background-color: #EEE; }`, `#div2 {margin: 0.3rem; color: red; background-color: #EEE; }` ); popup.show( { content: $.virtual(`
`).append(div1, div2), callback: () => $.removeCssRule(`#div1`, `#div2`) } );

params....rules: string[]. One or more complete css rules

instance_Style.description:
Delivers a utility object to manipulate styling of a JQL instance (element collection) or retrieve computed style value(s) from the first element of the element collection.
The available methods:
  • inline(rules:Object<string, string>) set the styling of all elements of the JQL instance collection using the style attribute (style="...")
  • inSheet(rules::Object<string, string>) set the styling of all elements of the JQL instance collection using the JQL custom stylesheet. When rules contains a className property, the className and the rules values will be added to the styleSheet, otherwise a intermediate className will be created for the given rules (see the example)
  • byRule({classes2Apply: Array<string>, rules: Array<string>}) Add one or more rules to the JQL custom stylesheet and (optionally) apply one or more classes to the concerning JQL Instance. See second example.
  • computed (getter) Retrieves the complete computedStyle of the first element of the JQL instance collection.
  • valueOf(key:string) Retrieve the computed value of a style property (see example)
Notes:
  • inline, inSheet and byRule return the JQL instance.
  • For the [key] value of valueOf you can either supply camel cased or dashed notation (e.g. "borderLeft" vs "border-left")
// inline const hello1 = $.virtual(`

`).Style .inline({ paddingLeft: `4px`, color: `white`, backgroundColor: `#000` }); const hello1Html = `HTML of hello1: ${hello1.HTML.get(true, true)}`; hello1.append(`
${hello1Html}
`); // inSheet with given className const hello2 = $.virtual(`

`).Style .inSheet({className: `leftRedBorder`, paddingLeft: `4px`, color: `green`, borderLeft: `12px solid red`}); const hello2Html = `HTML of hello2: ${hello2.HTML.get(true, true)}`; hello2.append(`
${hello2Html}
`); // inSheet, className generated const hello3 = $.virtual(`

`).Style .inSheet({paddingLeft: `4px`, color: `green`, borderLeft: `12px solid green`}); const hello3Html = `HTML of hello3: ${hello3.HTML.get(true, true)}`; hello3.append(`
${hello3Html}
`); const hello3GeneratedClassName = [...hello3[0]?.classList]?.shift(); // computed (note: randomNr is a utility function) const computedHello3 = $(`
`) .html(`hello3.Style.valueOf("borderLeftColor"): ${ hello3.toDOM().Style.valueOf(`borderLeftColor`)}.
  Equivalent hello3.Style.computed.borderLeftColor: ${ hello3.Style.computed.borderLeftColor}`); const computed = hello3.Style.computed; const sliceStart = randomNr(computed.length, 10) - 10; const hello3Computed = `

hello3.Style.computed (10 of ${computed.length} rules, random sample)
    ${ [...computed] .slice( sliceStart, sliceStart + 10) .map( (v) => `
  • ${v}: ${computed[v]}
    • `) .join(``) }
`.replace(/\n+\s{2,}/g, ` `); popup.show({ content: $(`
`).append(hello1, hello2, hello3, computedHello3, hello3Computed,), callback: () => $.removeCssRule(`.${hello3GeneratedClassName}`, `.leftRedBorder`) } ); const helloElem = $.virtual(`
Hello World
`); helloElem.Style.byRule( { classes2Apply: [`test1`], // Notes: // - the style rules are exactly what you would put in a css-file/style element // - you can add many rules here. Only [classes2Apply] will be relevant for the element at hand (here [helloElem]) rules: [ `.test1 { backgroundColor: #EEE; color: green }`, `.test2 { color: red; }`, `#test3 { color: blue; }`,] } ); helloElem.find$(`span`)?.addClass(`test2`); popup.show({ content: $(`
This resulted in:
`).attr({id: `test3`}).append(helloElem), callback: () => $.removeCssRule(`.test1`, `.test2`, `#test3`) });

static_fn.description:
Add custom method to JQL instances.
The first argument of function [fn] is the JQL instance. Calling the added method, you only need [...arguments]. See both examples for usage.
// we use the instance itself to set the title property $.fn(`addTitle`, (me, ttl) => ttl ? me.prop(`title`, ttl) : me); const someDiv = $.virtual(`
Hello world
`); popup.show( { content: someDiv .addTitle("hi there!") .append(`
My title is now "${someDiv.prop(`title`)}". Hover me!
`), callback: someDiv.remove, }); // we use the first element of the instance to colorize. Return [me] to not break the chain. $.fn( `colorRed`, me => { me[0].style.color = "red"; return me; } ); const someDiv = $.virtual(`
Hello world
`); popup.show( { content: someDiv.append($(`
There we have it
`).colorRed()), callback: someDiv.remove, });

instance_closest.description:
Return the parent element/node with css selector the closest (upwards) to the first element of the JQL instance collection. Equals Element.closest. The element returned is either new JQL instance (when something was found) or the original JQL instance (nothing found).
const someDiv = $(`
Hello world again
`, evt.target.closest(`.description`)); popup.show( { content: `someDiv.closest(".description").HTML.get(1, 1)
${ someDiv.closest(".description").HTML.get(1,1).slice(0, 100)}…`, });
